utterances: No. Everybody wants to look a little different.
Okay.
They want to be different than the other guy.
Any thoughts of retiring from the business?
When I can't stand up any longer, I'll retire.
Until then, I'll keep right on cutting.
Well Mr. Bozarth, thank you very much for talking with us about cutting hair here at Fort Dix.
Ernie Bozarth is the owner of Ernie's Barbershop in Browns Mills, New Jersey, and he joined us here at the Timmerman Center.
Now politics, and the Democrats' debate last night.
We're joined by two contributing writers to Slate.com's XX Factor column.
Emily Bazelon and Hanna Rosin, welcome to you both.
Thank you.
Thank you.
So how would last night help an undecided voter in Pennsylvania, with that primary just five days away now?
Well, it seems like from the polls the main issue that's coming up is honesty.
And that's a really hard one to decide.
You know, where you have all these - six in ten voters saying Hillary is not honest.
And so where would this debate lead you on that question of honesty?
It seemed that Hillary was trying very hard to be authentic.
You know, she was talking about her being the granddaughter of a factory worker in Scranton.
She wasn't sort of taking the bait and criticizing Obama so much.
Obama seemed, as we were just joking in the office right now, like the sort of slacker intern.
You know - too cool, kind of tired, not really willing to answer questions, not really willing to apologize.
And so, would that lead you to believe that she was more honest?
I don't know.
The papers this morning talk about how her performance was really good last night, or at least better than Obama's, but then they talk about how she's posturing to do a better performance.
So with Hillary there's always this sort of meta-layer of ""here is her new tactic."" Her new tactic is to be more authentic and less prickly.
So I don't know if that would lead you to believe she was more honest or wouldn't answer that question for you at all.
Emily, I see people writing overnight that ABC News conducted the worst debate yet.
(Soundbite of laughter)
The first 40 minutes utterly trivial, but then David Brooks from the New York Times says no, it was about character and it's revealing.
You know, at this point in the primaries, there aren't that many issue differences to plumb anymore.
There were a few numbers that came out last night about the capital gains tax that were a little bit different and the social security payroll tax.
But the first 40 minutes were about these, quote, ""character issues,"" that have gotten a lot of play in the last few weeks.

I think it would have been really surprising if Hillary hadn't been asked about why she fantasized about being under sniper fire, and if Obama hadn't been asked about these very controversial remarks that his former pastor Jeremiah Wright made.
I did not think it was a good debate, but not because the issues were trivial.
It's the way they outlined the issues, which I thought was trivial.
You need - you didn't need to sort of throw in the lapel pin and throw in Jeremiah Wright, which he's already answered pretty well.

If it were me I just would have focused on what I still think is the worst thing he's ever said, which is this cling quote, and just asked him a few questions about that and so it seemed a little more serious.

And asked her a few questions about Tuzla, which are both serious character-revealing issues, and seen who would rise to the occasion, but I don't think Obama can get away with saying it's trivial because he's built his campaign around character.
His book is about character.
It's about the various ways he was tested across his life.
He doesn't run on a policy campaign the way Hillary does, at least not so explicitly.
So he can't get mad when people ask him about things like his pastor or his patriotism or all these things that he claims to be a part of his character.

That's totally fair enough, but in all fairness the debate moderators, they were very careful to frame their questions in terms of how these issues affect the chances of whoever wins the nomination in November.
And that seems like it is the crucial issues with these various misstatements or just screw-ups that both Obama and Clinton have been guilty of in the last few weeks.
Is it going to affect their chances in November when now that the Republicans have all this tape to roll out?
And I also have to say, I personally learned something from their answers.
I mean, Obama keeps giving that same frustrating answer about what was genuinely an offensive quote, which is ""I can see how people were offended."" That's how he keeps starting his answer.
That's just a non-apology, whereas for Tuzla at least Hillary owned it.
At least she said I'm embarrassed, you know.
That sounds a little better to me than that I can see how people were offended, which he has repeated 20 times.
Right, she really did sound authentic.
Yeah.

The thing that is so interesting about the XX Factor column for me as a reader is that you all keep changing your positions about how you feel about these two candidates, and I wonder if you are changed by what you saw last night?
I think that this came out most strongly with Obama's quote, which began with Melinda Henneberger's great column.
And I think it's just, you know, you react day to day.
He is frustrating on this issue, and it is - it was a really bad answer and he's still not answering it.
So, I don't think it's that we've given up on Obama or that now we all love Hillary.
It's not quite like that.
It's just that we're stuck on this one issue because he won't help us get beyond it.
This is the bitter...
This is the bitter cling, you know, exactly, and his answer is just dishonest and unsatisfying, and it keeps staying that way.
And I think like everyone else we're having to live with these candidates for a long time.
Yeah, right!

And so inevitably there are moments in which they disillusion us, and the question is whether they are going to emerge from this primary process wounded in a way that is really going to hurt them in November.
Yeah, I mean, there hasn't been - we don't have moments of great Hillary love, which is you would think on that XX Factor's the one place you can find it.
But I'm trying to think back if there's been - we've had days when people have defended Hillary against other people's attacks, but an overflow of love for Hillary day hasn't come yet.
Right.
That she hadn't been knocked out early.
Right.
I remember that.
Some feminist guilt-style relief, exactly.
Yes.
And Emily, what about this prospect that they are - they're doing the work of Senator McCain?
I think that's a real concern.

They have both, in particular Hillary, given sound clips that are going to get played by the Republicans in the fall, because if you have a Democrat criticizing a Democrat, there's just a certain power in that.

And so this primary process is designed to go on for a long time, and we're seeing I suppose exactly what the people who designed it intended, but it does have this potentially detrimental effect for the Democrats in the fall.
Emily Bazelon and Hanna Rosin, they both are contributing writers at the XX Factor column at slate.com.
Thank you both again.
Thank you.
Thanks for having us.
Stay with us.
It's Day to Day from NPR News.
We've heard that the Democratic race will come down to the superdelegates.
In Washington State, nearly half of the 17 superdelegates are officially undecided.
One of them is David McDonald.
He's a long-time member of the Democratic National Committee.
Austin Jenkins of the Northwest News Network, went to see him in Seattle.
McDonald is one of those superdelegates whose name you don't recognize.
He's not a current or former politician.
He's a legal wonk, who's represented Microsoft for more than 20 years.
And so far, he hasn't picked a horse in the Democratic race.
I worked pretty hard in not letting myself get committed one way or the other.
Because McDonald sits on the DNC's Rules Committee, which is dealing with what to do about delegates from Michigan and Florida.
It's not a requirement that we stayed neutral in that committee.
But it did seem to me, given the level of emotion between the two campaigns, that it might be better to be uncommitted once I saw the issue coming down the pike.
McDonald says he'll pick a candidate by July 1st.
At that point, he'll consider a final plea from whichever candidate is trailing in delegates.
I suspect, it would be Clinton.
